unnormalised: Delhi Jal Board Announces Revised Water Tariff
normalised: Delhi Jal Board Announces Revised Water Tariff

unnormalised: The Delhi Jal Board (DJB) has announced a revised water tariff, effective 01/07/2024. The new rates will impact domestic and commercial consumers differently, with a focus on promoting responsible water usage. Consumers using up to 20,000 liters/month will continue to receive free water. However, consumption exceeding this limit will be charged at a rate of Rs. 5 per 1000 liters for the first 10,000 liters above the free limit, and Rs. 10 per 1000 liters thereafter.
normalised: The D-J-B has announced a revised water tariff, effective first July two thousand and twenty four. The new rates will impact domestic and commercial consumers differently, with a focus on promoting responsible water usage. Consumers using up to twenty thousand liters per month will continue to receive free water. However, consumption exceeding this limit will be charged at a rate of rupee five per one thousand liters for the first ten thousand liters above the free limit, and rupee ten per one thousand liters thereafter.

unnormalised: Commercial establishments will see a flat increase of 10% on their existing water bills. The DJB has also introduced a new penalty system for water wastage, particularly during peak hours (6:00 AM - 10:00 AM and 6:00 PM - 9:00 PM). Fines ranging from Rs. 500 to Rs. 2000 will be levied on households and businesses found using water for non-essential purposes, such as washing cars or watering lawns, during these times. This is according to notification no. DJB/Secy/2024/123.
normalised: Commercial establishments will see a flat increase of ten percent on their existing water bills. The D-J-B has also introduced a new penalty system for water wastage, particularly during peak hours (six A-M to ten A-M and six P-M to nine P-M). Fines ranging from rupee five hundred to rupee two thousand will be levied on households and businesses found using water for non-essential purposes, such as washing cars or watering lawns, during these times. This is according to notification number D-J-B slash S-e-c-y slash two thousand and twenty four slash one hundred and twenty three.

unnormalised: According to a DJB spokesperson, the revision aims to address the growing water scarcity in the city and encourage citizens to conserve this precious resource. The spokesperson added that the revenue generated from the increased tariffs will be used to improve the city’s water infrastructure and reduce leakages, with a projected reduction of 15% in water loss within the next 2 years. Citizens are advised to check their online bills at djb.gov.in for detailed calculations based on their consumption.
